Package jalds.alds.al.sorting.comparisonsort

Contains all of the Comparison Sort algorithms.

Class Summary
AbstractComparisonSort The base abstract comparison sort, implements Sort and provides helpfull methods to all of the comparison sort classes.
BinaryTreeSort A sort algorithm that first builds a binary search tree of the keys then accesses the keys with an in-order traversal.
BubbleSort Bubble sort has worst-case complexity O(n^2), where n is the number of items being sorted.
CocktailSort The algorithm differs from bubble sort in that sorts in both directions each pass through the list.
CombSort Every programmer knows that quicksort is the best in-memory sort in the world.
GnomeSort The simplest sort algorithm is not Bubble Sort..., it is not Insertion Sort..., it's Gnome Sort!
HeapSort Running time is O(n log n), is In Place
InPlaceMergeSort  
InsertionSort The insertion sort works just like its name suggests - it inserts each item into its proper place in the final list.
IntroSort  
MergeSort Merge sort or mergesort is an O(n log n) comparison-based sorting algorithm.
PatienceSort  
QuickSort QuickSort is an algorithm whose worst case running time is Q(n^2), but is remarkably efficient on the average and expected run time is )(n log n) This is a divide and conqure algorithm, on each run divides the given partation into elements less than and elements greater than a given piviot element, till it gets down to one element.
SelectionSort Selection sort is a sorting algorithm, specifically an in-place comparison sort.
ShellSort Invented by Donald Shell in 1959, the shell sort is the most efficient of the O(n^2) class of sorting algorithms.
SmoothSort  
StrandSort  
 

Package jalds.alds.al.sorting.comparisonsort Description

Contains all of the Comparison Sort algorithms.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_sort

A Comparison Sort is a type of sorting algorithm that only reads the list elements through a single abstract comparison operation (often a "less than or equal to" operator) that determines which of two elements should occur first in the final sorted list. The only requirement is that the operator obey the three defining properties of a total order:

  • if a = b and b = a then a = b (antisymmetry)
  • if a = b and b = c then a = c (transitivity)
  • a = b or b = a (totalness or trichotomy)

A metaphor for thinking about comparison sorts is that you have a set of unlabelled weights and a balance scale. The goal is to line up the weights in order by their weight without any information except that obtained by placing two weights on the scale and seeing which one is heavier (or if they weigh the same).
